title: 2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry

title_detail.value: 2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry

summary:
Via a special dimensional reduction, that is, Fourier transforming over one
of the coordinates of Casimir operator of su(2) Lie algebra and 4-oscillator
Hamiltonian, we have obtained 2 and 3 dimensional Hamiltonian with shape
invariance symmetry. Using this symmetry we have obtained their eigenspectrum.
In the mean time we show equivalence of shape invariance symmetry and Lie
algebraic symmetry of these Hamiltonians.

summary_detail.value:
Via a special dimensional reduction, that is, Fourier transforming over one
of the coordinates of Casimir operator of su(2) Lie algebra and 4-oscillator
Hamiltonian, we have obtained 2 and 3 dimensional Hamiltonian with shape
invariance symmetry. Using this symmetry we have obtained their eigenspectrum.
In the mean time we show equivalence of shape invariance symmetry and Lie
algebraic symmetry of these Hamiltonians.

author: E. Faizi
fulltext:
arXiv:math-ph/0005019v1 16 May 2000

2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape
Invariance Symmetry
M. A. Jafarizadeh

a

a,b,c ∗

, H. Panahi-Talemi a, †and E. Faizi

a, ‡

Department of Theoretical Physics and Astrophysics, Tabriz University, Tabriz 51664, Iran.
b

Institute for Studies in Theoretical Physics and Mathematics, Teheran 19395-1795, Iran.
c

Pure and Applied Science Research Center, Tabriz 51664, Iran.

November 7, 2018

Abstract
Via a special dimensional reduction, that is, Fourier transforming over one of the
coordinates of Casimir operator of su(2) Lie algebra and 4-oscillator Hamiltonian, we
have obtained 2 and 3 dimensional Hamiltonian with shape invariance symmetry. Using this symmetry we have obtained their eigenspectrum. In the mean time we show
equivalence of shape invariance symmetry and Lie algebraic symmetry of these Hamiltonians.
∗

E-mail:jafarzadeh@ark.tabrizu.ac.ir

†

E-mail:t-panahi@ark.tabrizu.ac.ir

‡

E-mail:msph@ark.tabrizu.ac.ir

1

 2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry
Keywords: Lie Algebra, Exactly Solvable, Shape Invariance, Fourier Transformation .
PACs numbers: 05.45.Ra, 05.45.Jn, 05.45.Tp

2

 2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry

I

3

INTRODUCTION

Exactly solvable quantum Hamiltonians (ESQH) have always attracted a lot of interest
in theoretical physics and mathematical physics. Hence, construction of exactly solvable
models is of great interest [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. Familiar solvable potentials (particularly onedimensional one) have the property of shape invariance, where this property has played an
important role in calclulation of their determinant by Heat Kernel method [6, 7, 8, 9, 10] . For
these potentials, eigenvalues and eigenvectors can be derived using the well known methods
of supersymmetric quantum mechanics together with shape invariant factorization. The
majority of potentials have also been shown to possess a Lie algebraic symmetry and hence
are also solvable by group theoretical techniques. Actually one can establish a connection
between ESQH with shape invariance symmetry and ESQH with Lie algebraic symmetry
and can show that they are indeed equivalent [11, 12]. One of the authors has introduced
some 2 and 3-dimensional shape invariant Hamiltonians [13, 14, 15]. In theses article they
have shown that the shape invariance symmetry of these models is due to the existence of
some Lie algebraic symmetry. Hence, in this article we construct new 2 and 3-dimensional
EQSH with shape invariance symmetry, where su(2) and Heisenberg algebra are responsible
for the existence of shape invariance symmetry in them.
This paper is organized as follows: In section II, using the left and right invariant vector
fields of su(2) Lie algebra we first construct its Casimir operator. Then via Fourier transformation over one of the coordinates we construct 2-dimensional Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ) which
possess shape invariance symmetry. Using this symmetry we obtain its eigenspectrum analytically. In section III, starting with Hamiltonian of 4-oscillator and Fourier transforming
over one of the coordinates, we obtain 3-dimensional Hamiltonian corresponding to motion of a charged particle in presence of an electric field. We show that this 3-dimensional
Hamiltonian possess a shape invariance symmetry and using this symmetry we obtain its
eigenspectrum. What is so important in both models is that both Hamiltonians factorize

 4

2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry

shape invariantly into a product of second order differential operators. These second order
operators themselves consist of the product of first order differential operators. The paper
ends with a brief conclusion.

2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry

II.3

Algebraic Solution of Hq (θ, ψ) Hamiltonian

In order to obtain eigenspectrum of Hamiltonian (2.17) by algebraic method, first we obtain eigenspectrum of the Casimir operator (2.11). Since this operator commutes with left
and right invariant generators given in (2.10), therefore, we can obtain representation of
su(2) simply by finding simultaneous eigenfunctions of the set of commuting operators,
(R3 , L3 , L2 ). Denoting their simultaneous eigenfunction by χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ), we can write
L2 χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ) = l(l + 1)χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ),

(2.24)

L3 χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ) = mL χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ),

(2.25)

R3 χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ) = mR χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ).

(2.26)

Now solving the difference of the first order differential equations (2.25) and (2.26) we deduce
that χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ) is proportional to e−i(mR −mL )φ , hence we have

χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ) =

e−i(mR −mL )φ f (θ, ψ), where f (θ, ψ) can be determined from the solution of the sum of the
equations (2.25) and (2.26), that is
− i cos(θ)∂ψ f (θ, ψ) + i sin(θ) cot(ψ)∂θ f (θ, ψ) = (mL + mR )f (θ, ψ).

(2.27)

Now considering the highest weight defined by mL = −mR = l. this happenes if the right
hand side of the equation (2.27) vanishes, hence it can be solved by characteristic method
which leads to the following results:
χll,−l (θ, ψ, φ) = exp(2ilφ)f max (sin(ψ) sin(θ))
where f max is an arbitrary function which can be determined by solving the first order
differential equation:
R+ χll,−l (θ, ψ, φ) = 0,

L+ χll,−l (θ, ψ, φ) = 0.

(2.28)

and L− over the highest eigenfunction, that is, we have
χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ) = (L− )l−mL (R− )l+mR (e2ilφ (sin(ψ) sin(θ))2l ).

χlmL ,mR (θ, ψ, φ) = ei(mL −mR )φ L− (mL − mR + 1)L− (mL − mR + 2)...

2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry

Since the left and right invariant generators commute with each other, we can exchange
these operators in (2.29) before Fourier transformation, whereas after Fourier transformation,
we can use only the relation L− (q)R− (q − 1) = R− (q)L− (q − 1). Since the Hamiltonian
Hq (θ, ψ) can be obtained from the relations (2.15) and (2.17) via similarity transformation
and gauge transformation, we have:
Hq (θ, ψ) = exp(−ξ)L2q (θ, ψ) exp(ξ), L2q (θ, ψ)χlq,m (θ, ψ) = l(l + 1)χlq,m (θ, ψ),

(2.34)

where ξ = − 12 ln(sin(ψ) sin(θ)). Hence eigenfunction of Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ) can be written
as:
χ̃lq,m (θ, ψ) = exp(−ξ)χlq,m (θ, ψ).

II.4

(2.35)

Shape Invariance Symmetry of Hq (θ, ψ)

Here in this section we show that the Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ) possess both degeneracy and
shape invariance symmetry [1, 2, 3]. As it is shown in section (II.3), functions χ̃lq,m (θ, ψ) =
1

(sin(ψ) sin(θ)) 2 χlq,m (θ, ψ) are eigenfunctions of Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ) with the corresponding
eigenvalue l(l + 1). Since |mR | ≤ l and |mL | ≤ l, therefore, |q| ≤ 2l and for a given value of
q the parameter m can take the following values:
m=

Since the eigenvalue of Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ) is independent of m, therefore it has (2l+1−|q|)
degenerate states for a given l or given energy l(l + 1). To see the shape invariance symmetry
of Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ), first we consider the Fourier transformed left and right invariant
vector fields:

(2.47)
(2.48)

The above relations imply that the pair of operators (L− , R+ ) [(L+ , R− )] map degenerate
eigenstates of Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ) for a given value of q into each other, that is they
decrease [increase] the quantum number m by 2 units as follows:
L− (q + 1)R+ (q)χlq,m(θ, ψ) = A+ (q, m)B− (q + 1, m − 1)χlq,m−2 (θ, ψ),
L+ (q − 1)R− (q)χlq,m (θ, ψ) = A− (q, m)B+ (q − 1, m + 1)χlq,m+2 (θ, ψ).
Now introducing the operator Y+ (q) := L+ (q − 1)R− (q) and Y− (q) := L− (q + 1)R+ (q) as
the raising and lowering operators of degenerates states of Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ), we have
the following shape invariance like symmetry between the degenerate states of Hamiltonian
Hq (θ, ψ):
Y− (q)Y+ (q)χlq,m (θ, ψ) = E(q, m)χlq,m (θ, ψ)
Y+ (q)Y− (q)χlq,m+2 (θ, ψ) = E(q, m)χlq,m+2 (θ, ψ)
where
E(q, m) = A− (q, m)A+ (q, m + 2)B− (q + 1, m + 1)B+ (q − 1, m + 1).
Thus, for a given value of q, we can obtain eigenfunction of Hamiltonian Hq (θ, ψ) with
eigenvalue l(l + 1), simply by acting the pairs of operators (L− , R+ )[(L+ , R− )] over the
highest weight [lowest weight], where here we have derived the eigenfunction χlq,m (θ, ψ) by
acting the lowering operator over the highest eigenstate as follows:
χlq,m (θ, ψ) = k −1 (Y− (q))

Using the relation (2.33) we can obtain the highest weight eigenstates for q > 0 and q < 0,

χlq,(2l−|q|)(θ, ψ) =

f or q < 0

R− (q + 1)R− (q + 2)...R− (2l)(sin(θ) sin(ψ))2l f or q > 0.

On the other hand pair operator (L+ , R+ )[or(L− , R− )] leave the eigenvalue m and l
unchanged while they increase [decrease] the parameter q by 2 units, that is they map
eigenfunction of Hamiltonian corresponding to the same energy with different q into each
other. That is, they map isospectral Hamiltonian into each other, which nothing but shape
invariance. In order to show this shape invariance symmetry, we act the related operators
over χlq,m (θ, ψ), we then obtain:
L+ (q + 1)R+ (q)χlq,m (θ, ψ) = A+ (q, m)B+ (q + 1, m − 1)χlq+2,m (θ, ψ)
L− (q − 1)R− (q)χlq,m (θ, ψ) = A− (q, m)B− (q − 1, m + 1)χlq−2,m (θ, ψ),
obviously, the combined action of above operators leave the eigenvalues m and l unchanged
while changing the parameter q by 2-units. Hence we define the operator X+ (q) := L+ (q +
1)R+ (q) and X− (q) := L− (q + 1)R− (q + 2) as raising and lowering operators of parameter
q. Then the shape invariance symmetry means:
X− (q)X+ (q)χlq,m (θ, ψ) = N(q, m)χlq,m (θ, ψ)
X+ (q)X− (q)χlq+2,m (θ, ψ) = N(q, m)χlq+2,m (θ, ψ)
where
N(q, m) = A+ (q, m)A− (q + 2, m)B+ (q + 1, m − 1)B− (q + 1, m + 1)
or
N(q, m) =

1
(2l − m − q)(2l + m + q + 2)
16

 15

q

× (2l − m + q)(2l − m + q + 4)(2l + m − q + 2)(2l + m − q − 2).
For fixed values of energy l(l + 1) and given values of m, the parameter q can take the
following values
q = (2l − |m|), (2l − |m| − 2), ..., −(2l − |m| − 2), −(2l − |m|).
Hence obtaining the highest eigenstates, by solving the following first order differential equation
X+ (2l − |m|)χl(2l−|m|),m (θ, ψ) = 0
where its integral leads to
χl(2l−|m|),m (θ, ψ)

R− (2l − m + 1)R− (2l − m + 2)...R− (2l)(sin(θ) sin(ψ))2l f or m > 0.

Therefore using the shape invariance relation, we can obtain the eigenstates of Hamiltonian
Hq (θ, ψ) by consecutive action of q-lowering operator over q-highest weight eigenstate,
χlq,m (θ, ψ) = f −1 X− (q)X− (q + 2)...X− (2l − |m| − 4)X− (2l − |m| − 2)χl(2l−|m|),m (θ, ψ)

III

3-dimensional Hamiltonian obtained from
4-Oscillators

Here in this section using the su(2)-parametrization of previous section, we obtain a special
3-dimensional Hamiltonian from the Hamiltonian of 4-oscillator with the same frequency,
where we obtain its spectrum via the corresponding spectrum of 4-oscillator Hamiltonian.

It is straightforward to derive the following relation between Hamiltonian (3.12) and operator
Ai (m)(A†i (m)), i= 1, 2:
H(m − 1)A†1 (m) − A†1 (m)H(m) = ωA†1 (m),
H(m + 1)A†2 (m) − A†2 (m)H(m) = ωA†2 (m),

H(m + 1)A1 (m) − A1 (m)H(m) = −ωA1 (m),
H(m − 1)A2 (m) − A2 (m)H(m) = −ωA2 (m),

(3.19)

 20

2 and 3-dimensional Hamiltonians with Shape Invariance Symmetry

where H(m) := Hm (r, θ, ψ). The above relations indicate that Hamiltonian (3.12) possesses
shape invariance symmetry. To see this, we consider the Fourier transformation of eigenvalue
equation (3.9):
H(m)Ψ(n,m,n3 ,n4 ) (r, θ, ψ) = E(n,n3 ,n4 ) Ψ(n,m,n3 ,n4 ) (r, θ, ψ),

(3.20)

where n = n1 + n2 , m = n2 − n1 and E(n,n3 ,n4 ) = (n + n3 + n4 + 2)ω. Since n1 and n2 are
positive integers, therefore n is also a positive integer but m is an integer. For a given value
of m, the quantum number n can be either even or odd integer, since, quantum numbers
n1 and n2 vary by the same amount, so that m remains constant. Actually for some given
value of m, the quantum number n can take the following values
n = |m|, |m| + 2, |m| + 4, ... .
On the other hand, in terms of n, the quantum number m can take the following values
m = −n, −n + 2, ..., n − 2, n .
It is interesting to see that energy of Hamiltonian Hm (r, θ, ψ) is independent of m, hence
these Hamiltonians are isospectral which is due to the existence of shape invariance symmetry
as we show below.
Operating the operator A†1 (m) on both sides of the eigenvalue relation (3.20) and using
the relations (3.19), we get
H(m − 1)(A†1 (m)Ψn,m (r, θ, ψ)) = (En + ω)(A†1(m)Ψn,m (r, θ, ψ)),
therefore, A†1 (m)Ψn,m (r, θ, ψ)) corresponds to the eigenfunction of H(m−1) with corresponding eigenvalue En+1 , that is
A†1 (m)Ψn,m (r, θ, ψ) =

s

n−m
+ 1Ψn+1,m−1 (r, θ, ψ),
2

where Ψn,m (r, θ, ψ) := Ψ(n,m,n3 ,n4 ) (r, θ, ψ) and En := E(n,n3 ,n4 ) . Similarly, operating A†2 (m)
on both sides of (3.20) and using (3.19) we get:
H(m + 1)(A†2 (m)Ψn,m (r, θ, ψ)) = (En + ω)(A†2 (m)Ψn,m (r, θ, ψ)),

CONCLUSION

Here in this work having Fourier transformed 3 and 4-dimensional Hamiltonians associated
with su(2) and Heisenberg Lie algebra we have been able to obtain 2 and 3-dimensional
Hamiltonian whit shape invariance symmetry. It would be interesting to obtain many-body
Hamiltonian in one dimension or higher, which possesses shape invariance symmetry by
appropriate Fourier transformation over some coordinates of Hamiltonian associated with
higher ranks semisimple and non semisimple Lie algebra. This is under investigation.
